VPTeX
Class ExpressionTree

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--VPTeX.ExpressionTree
public class ExpressionTree
extends java.lang.Object

An ExpressionTree is a datastructure capable of holding a whole VectorPascal expression. An expression can be a procedure call, or the Left/Right Hand Side of the := in an assignment. An expression can also occur in a declaration. ExpressionTree is NOT designed to hold type definitions. ExpressionTree can be build up incrementally using various constructors and methods. toString is overridden to get a string representation for the contents of 'this' ExpressionTree. toString_ommitDollars offers a way of displaying a String if you're already in mathsmode, and don't want to repeat the dollars (which would have caused latex errors).

Constructor Detail

ExpressionTree

public ExpressionTree()
Create a new empty expression tree.

ExpressionTree

public ExpressionTree(java.lang.String val)
Create a new ExpressionTree. (Used to create a single identifier or litteral.)
Parameters:
val - the value of 'this' (single node) ExpressionTree

ExpressionTree

public ExpressionTree(java.lang.String val,
                      int nodeType)
               throws SyntaxError
Create a new empty ExpressionTree, and define it's type. This is useful to distinguish functions and arrays from single variables.
Parameters:
val - the value of 'this' ExpressionTree.
nodeType - the type of this node (e.g. FUNCTION_CALL).

ExpressionTree

public ExpressionTree(java.lang.String val,
                      ExpressionTree setConstruction,
                      ExpressionTree variableIdentification)
Create a new 'perm' ExpressionTree. Useful for the special case of a permutation. Caution: The ExpressionTree paramaters should normally be a set construction and a variable identification (respectively). Attempts to do otherwise will be successful, and may generate unsensible output.
Parameters:
val - Normally "perm".
setConstruction - The first parameter (Normally a set construction)
variableIdentification - The second parameter (Normally any variable identification)

ExpressionTree

public ExpressionTree(java.lang.String val,
                      int nodeType,
                      boolean brackets)
               throws SyntaxError
Create a new empty ExpressionTree, define it's type, and whether to enclose the parameters within brackets. This is useful to distinguish functions and arrays from single variables.
Parameters:
val - the value of 'this' ExpressionTree.
nodeType - the type of this node (e.g. ARRAY_REFERENCE).
brackets - True if the function parameters should be within brackets.

ExpressionTree

public ExpressionTree(ExpressionTree cond,
                      ExpressionTree ifTrue,
                      ExpressionTree ifFalse)
Create a new ExpressionTree to represent a conditional update
Parameters:
cond - the condition that determines the update.
ifTrue - the value that would be given by the expression if cond be true.
ifFalse - the value that would be given by the expression if cond be false.

bracket

addRightSubexpression

public void addRightSubexpression(ExpressionTree that)
Adds the expression in 'that' to the children of 'this'. (Applies to Arrays, giving them an additional subscript-field (to the right of the others - if any) Applies to Function calls - giving them an additional parameter.)
Parameters:
that - the subexpression we want to add to this function/array.

applyUnary

public void applyUnary(java.lang.String optr)
                throws OperatorError
Applies a unary operator to 'this' ExpressionTree.
Parameters:
optr - The operator to be applied to 'this' ExpressionTree.

applyUnary

public void applyUnary(java.lang.String optr,
                       boolean brackets)
                throws OperatorError
Applies a unary operator to 'this' ExpressionTree.
Parameters:
optr - the operator we want to apply to 'this' ExpressionTree.
brackets - true if there should be brackets around the operand of the unary operator.

applyRight

public void applyRight(java.lang.String optr,
                       java.lang.String operand)
                throws OperatorError
Applies an operation (dyadic operator, operand) to the right of 'this' ExpressionTree. Ignores the operator if the tree is empty (just inserts the value.) Effectively changes 'this' to "this optr operand" (infix-notation).
Parameters:
optr - The operator to apply.
opearand - The other operand.

applyRight

public void applyRight(java.lang.String optr,
                       ExpressionTree that)
                throws OperatorError
Applies an operation (dyadic operator, operand) to the right of 'this' ExpressionTree. Ignores the operator if the tree is empty (just inserts the value.) Effectively changes 'this' to "this optr that" (infix-notation).
Parameters:
optr - The operator to apply.
that - The other operand.

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Returns a String representation of 'this' ExpressionTree.
Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
Returns:
String - The string to be displayed.

toString

public java.lang.String toString(double maximumWidth)
Returns a String representation of 'this' ExpressionTree.
Parameters:
maximumWidth - Currantly redundant. The maximum width of the outputString before it must be broken up into lines.
Returns:
String - The String to be displayed.

toString_ommitDollars

public java.lang.String toString_ommitDollars()
Returns a String-representation of 'this' ExpressionTree. Ommits all $-characters which are used to toggle between maths-mode and latex-mode. This is useful for expressions that are nested within mathematical expressions.
Returns:
String - The String to be displayed.
